												☺ Easy to play.☺ Local co-op.☺ Suitable for most ages.☹ Short.☹ Difficulty spikes.Pressure can be summed up rather easily, short and sweet. The gameplay is a cross between a racer and shoot em up where you control a steam powered buggy and have to contend with a variety of enemies as you try to make it to the finish line without running out of steam...literally, if you dordle or allow one too many enemies to escape you'll not have enough pressure to keep your buggy going and grind to a halt.After a race you have the option to spend any coins collected to upgrade your buggy with a variety of weapons, tools, rams and a beefier buggy and while it doesn't really change how the game plays, the upgrades are very much required to progress and even on Normal Difficulty, you may hit some challenging spikes in difficulty. This isn't helped by seemingly being unable to redo won races during the campaign to collect more coins for upgrades - at one stage, I had to sell all previous unlocks in order to buy the parts needed to give me a fighting chance.Levels are largely similar, hold accelerate and fire and hurtle towards the finish line, boosting when available. Of special note are the few 'boss' levels which I found very enjoyable and changed up the pace of things enough to keep the game engaging.The presentation is lovely and the couple of cutscenes are humorous. It controlled well with an XBox Controller and was certainly playable, though slightly clunky with keyboard controls and the entire game can be played in local co-op and although Online Multiplayer is an option, at the time of playing there were no servers available.Pressure is rather enjoyable but very short, crossing the finish line at around three hours to clear the campaign races. It's certainly hard to recommend this game at full price as a result of this, but what's on offer is well polished and fun - if you want a game to play with your kids and you happen to see this game on offer, I'd say give it a go!

Pressure is a racing combat arcade game. You play as Morgan, a young man in his steam-powered attack vehicle, racing across the land battling evil minions to get the lake's water back from Count Soap II, who stole all of it to force the inhabitants to use his spa facilities.Pros: Nice game for all ages with colorful graphics and humoristic characters. You don't race against time, but instead against the loss of pressure you vehicle has, which is replenished from fighting off other wacky vehicles and passing check points. You have a multitude of upgrades you can purchase between races, whether car chassis, bumper, main weapon and secondary weapon. There's a long list of varied levels with little repetition, and an increasing variety of baddies to shoot, some straightforward and some requiring specific tactics.Cons: There is no story development to speak of (not that the game needs any). The game's focus isn't on the racing itself, but on completing the levels while killing all baddies and picking coins, so once completed there is little incentive to go back just to beat your time. The campaign mode doesn't allow to play back other levels, so you can't use your progression to do better in a past level.Verdict: ★★★★☆ - Next on your list!As far as arcade-style games go, this is a fun one to play. Levels are quick, so you can hop in for a few levels and leave, great for young gamers, casual gamers, or anyone looking for short play sessions. The game is exactly what it advertises to be, so if it looks interesting to you, knock yourself out!—————————————————————————This was just my opinion.If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up, and feel free to check out more of my (purely opinionated) reviews.

This is a long review, so if you want a brief summary of why I recommend Pressure just skip to Results and read from there.Chasing Carrots creates a fun shoot 'em up arcade style driving game that keeps you on your toes. With silly lines and a rediculous story Pressure is the type of game that really pushes you at every turn. Story:Pressure, despite its low Metascore and rather dull describing reviews it’s actually quite a riveting game. Not too long, but fun till the end. Pressure has a rather funny, but very simple story. Pressure is about a young man who lives by a lake awakening to all the water being stolen. Who is the culprit you may ask? Well none other than an evil Sauna genius who decided to charge all of the community to use the lakes water from his sauna. In order to retrieve this water back from the depths of the evil sauna you must race through rivers, cliffs, mountains, buildings, and railways in order to defeat the evil geniuses waves of monsters. Gameplay:The levels are not timed with an actual timer, but rather a pressure gauge. As time moves on, the more you are hit, or as you progress through the course you gain or lose pressure. If the gauge goes to zero your car conks out and you lose the match. On the other hand if your car gets too shot up it can take extensive damage and blow up. So in order to win the race you need to go fast, avoid the bullets, and kill all the enemies. The game allows you to boost unlimited times, with each car offering different boost lengths, shoot unlimited ammo with many different guns, and use power ups. This game is like a blood bath, minus the blood and adding water. Results:The game isn't very difficult; it just has some interesting concepts which until you figure out how to properly use the game it seems rather difficult. With constant boosting, unlimited ammo, and nuclear weapons Pressure is a shoot 'em up racing game. Pressure offers a small campaign with multiplayer experience and brilliant high pressure (hah) action that keeps you on your toes. Don't be fooled you won't be racing against opponents in this epic as you'll be too focused on destroying everyone and everything in your way. If you like games where you can sit down for a short session and not have to dedicate too much time this is the game for you.Pros:+Smooth, easy gameplay+Smart difficulty curve+Simple but pleasant graphics+Friendly story with simple characters+Fast shoot 'em up gameplay+Loads of upgrades that allow you to customize and further boost your car.+Funny little story that isn't in any way inappropriate. +Lots of interesting baddies and boss fights to keep you interested.+Unlimited boosts and ammo, so you don't feel like you have to hold back.Cons-Not a racing game-Enemies seem to repeat themselves after you complete the first world-Hints are not given randomly, but rather as you progress throughout the game-You cannot go back and play an old level in the campaign to grind up your car (if you are having difficulties)

												The controls for this game are really wonky. You'd think that a controller would be the best way to go with a game like this, but it really isn't. I found the controls much more intuitive with a mouse and keyboard.There is no map of the track, and the isometric view means you can't see much of the road ahead of you. At first I was like, "What kind of crappy racing game is this?" but then I realized that it's more of an arcade game than a racing one.You zoom through the game, avoiding obstacles and shooting bad guys. I'm not particularly great at either those things, but I am good at one thing: crashing. So I upgraded my car with a bunch of armor and some spikey rams, and I crashed into my enemies to my heart's content.The graphics are very cool, the soundtrack is fun, and (once you get used to the weird controls) the car controls respond quite well to your commands.The game was extremely fun at first, but it got very repetitive very quickly. The first boss fight was interesting. After that, there was a bunch more of the same ol', same ol'. Second boss fight: different and interesting. Then more boredom (oh but this time they removed most of the walls on the sides, so I actually had to pay attention to where I was driving instead of crashing into the sides, hee hee).There are new enemies introduced gradually, but they don't really change the gameplay very much. You still just zoom around, shooting or ramming them.You collect coins as you progress through the game, which you can then use to upgrade your vehicle. This process is a familiar game mechanic but is also confusing. None of the upgrades tell you what exactly you're buying. I bought a new gun, and only after using it was I able to say, "Ahh, I see. This gun is way more powerful but has a slower rate of fire." But nowhere does it tell you if the power on the basic version of this gun is equal to or better than a fully upgraded version of the previous gun. I'm not much of a number cruncher, but I would still like to know the basic stats of the equipment I am buying.If you want to go back and re-play levels (to get more coins or get a better score or something), you select "Free Play" from the single-player menu. I mention this because the campaign mode shows the entire map and doesn't let you go back to previous levels, which at first led me to believe that you were unable to revisit them.There is a multiplayer mode, which I presume would be fun to goof around in like a party game.It only took me about three hours to buy the best equipment for my car and complete the game. I might go back and try to get a better score on previous levels, but in all honesty, the game has little to no replayability. The repetitive gameplay might be okay if there were cool new paintjobs you could buy for your car or something, but as it is, I've already bought everything in one imperfect playthrough. This game needs something, anything that would give the player an incentive to pick it up and play again.If you can buy this game very cheap, it is definitely worth it. I had a coupon and picked it up for $1, and I definitely got more than a dollar's worth of entertainment out of it. I'm glad I didn't pay any more than that though.If you want a good-looking, fun little arcade game to play in short sessions, you will probably like this game.If you're expecting anything more than that, don't buy it.

												Pressure is the kind of game you play when you're sick and tired of having everything get in your way. The concept's simple enough: everything in front of, to the side of, or even near you, dies. Either by shooting them with a variety of steampunk weaponry, or by ramming them to shreds. Either way you're in for a good time.There are a few issues here and there though. The biggest is that it's short. Like really short. It's a fun destructive experience but the only real replay value is in trying to get the best score in Freeplay mode. Secondly, the weaponry offers a variety of gameplay styles but ultimately the last weapon in the list is the best, and the later levels aren't as enjoyable without it. It's good for what it offers though. What also stinks is that all sorts of new things are introduced in the first third of the game, but as time goes on, the game does begin to drag a bit. Finally, there are only three cutscenes in the game, which isn't really a huge complaint, but the game's charming and funny so it's just nice to see the amount of life the creators put into it.Despite the complaints, the soundtrack is funky and well composed, gameplay is solid and works for you more than it works for your enemies, difficulty is a bit wonky here and there, and, again, the game's full of charm and fun as a cartoony game should be. So an easy recommendation if you want something to kill a little time with.

												Certainly fun and interesting, but not quite fully realized or well-executed.  What you see is pretty much what you get, except that's pretty much it for the whole game.  You fight a "time limit" while trying to compete in a pseudo-score attack environment while staying alive, and all of that together combined with the chaos of the hordes of enemies swarming around you is great, at least for a while.The only thing that really changes throughout the game is how much health your enemies have and your environment.  With the proper couple of upgrades, I found myself nearly invincible and mostly just annoyed at how much health (on the enemies) that was thrown at me.  Little strategy was needed in just slamming my face into the enemies over and over to destroy them as quickly as possible, and I even binged on offense and used a low grade of defense for over half the campaign in terms of upgrades.The camera angle doesn't allow you to effectively gather the coins, so picking those up is mostly luck.  Got an "all-ages" thing going with the pretty cringey sense of humor and honestly lame scenarios, aside from the "grand plan".  Can't say I've ever seen that before.Bottom line, it's certainly worth a look and a single (pretty short) playthrough, but it doesn't have much staying power or any outstanding moments.  The 10 dollar price tag is iffy, but at least the game feels like they tried.

												Pressure is a very polarising game. While the game mechanics itself is simple: you have this "steam" car and you need to reach the end of the course without running out of steam, and there are bazillion enemies to get in your way out to make sure you don't finish... but you can shoot them. What does that have to do with foiling a criminal mastermind's plan to create the ultimate spa by sucking up every drop of water in the river? Almost nothing. The game plays a bit like River Raid / 1942 and similar genre with vehicles that can overtake you, vehicles started from the sidelines, stationary turrets and obstacles (that slows you down if you hit them) and so on. There are even occasional "bosses" (super-large vehicles). The only change from the formula is basically the road curves this way and that, and you need to turn, and it's isometric / top-down hybrid view. Your vehicle shoots only straight ahead, so aiming is a bit of a problem as you must turn the entire vehicle to aim. You do, however, have a good selection of weapons... If you managed to soak up enough gold coins on the course to afford them. There are a lot of different things to upgrade on the vehicle, from type or grade of weapons to speed / agility of the vehicle to ramming power, and much more. But they don't feel *that* different. Your basic machine gun, upgraded, seem to work fine, at least for the earliest 10-20 missions. There is quite a bit of humor, and definitely PG if not G outright. And graphics are good, but somehow I never really liked the game.

												If you're anywhere near my age and played the Crash Bandicoot racing game, you'll find a similar feel and artistic style in this with an updated look and suspiciously odd similarities to certain Pixar/Disney 3D CG films; Pressure builds (pardon the pun) a great deal of fun in to an exciting game. Yes, this game type has been done many times before, but the developers managed to capture enough nostalgia and fresh fun to keep things interesting throughout. You could purchase the game early in the morning and finish at least one of the modes of it by lunchtime or early afternoon, which makes it a great thing to play if you're looking for something that you can easily get from beginning to end in a short time. Again, it has the feel of a Crash Bandicoot style game with its overt zanyness and fast-paced gameplay. The worst thing I can honestly say about this game is that it seems to be aimed toward a certain age group and there are certain things that may be considered inappropriate for that age group. As something that can be a lot of fun for people of all ages, I did find myself being somewhat overwhelmed by the "cute" factor at times. Is this a drawback? To some it may be, I found the use of adorable artwork and funny characters to be charming in one way, and irritating in another. The other major critique I have is in regards to the music in the game. With very little variety, you're likely to be putting the volume of it on mute and listening to your favorite album(s) in the background while playing the game itself. While this may not seem like a big deal, a soundtrack can lend a great deal toward my overall interest in replaying a game In short I would give the game a 6.5 out of 10, and would bump it up a star if the soundtrack weren't so amateurish and irritating. The voice acting is funny, but it would've been nicer to have something interesting to listen to while actually inside of a level, and maybe some minibosses toward the end of each level, I don't think that other than the major bosses there's anything that could be considered a "boss" or what have you. About as much fun as you could pack in to 4 hours of gaming, even if repeated playthrough is a bit unlikely because of the structure and overall repetition of the game. I noticed very little difference between play modes other than getting slightly more irritated with the same things you have to keep an eye in on all of them. .

												While I had seen somewhat mixed (edging towards positive) reviews on this game, this is the kind that got my attention by its playthrough videos and screenshots. Sure enough, I was not disappointed when I gave it a shot myself. You can get my first impressions of this title in this video:


YouTube™ Video: Pressure - 3D First Impressions 

			Views: 40		

			Taking a look at a cool little indie game of a genre I would call a tantalizing encounter between racing game and shoot em' up!		

* Warning: Steam though it would be a good idea to break all stereoscopic videos. Head to YT to watch it, make sure you are using Flash, not HTML5.First off, maybe I'll get lenient because the game works very well with Tridef Ignition in stereo-3D using the driver's 2D+depth feature (Power 3D). The game simply looks excellent with added depth perception and given its nature, it adds all that much more to the experience, even going as far as helping the game play a lot!Some can give it criticism for not having enough varied shmup features while others can find the lack of actual racing elements  sort of a letdown, for its price (even more so when it lands on sale) it actually falls very well within my expecations and the 10$ range sort of opens up tolerance for elements that may lack, but do not bring down the gameplay itself in a notable way.Don't be too surprised - this is in NO way a racing game - rather a different take on a shmup, this one being loaded with SPEEDING elements. You won't beat anything by passing rather you have to speed through the levels and defeat the enemies with your gun, not your driving. In fact you're encouraged to drive THROUGH enemies, not around them (which I find quite satisfying; the ram mechanics are funny).My only valid criticism could be on that aspect. I see this game as a sort of buildup to what it would've actually liked to be. This is sort of the beginning of the genre and I hope they can build a sequel and attempt to experiment more with an ACTUAL racing / shmup balance. This concept would definitely benefit from more actual race-like elements and maybe a POV that gives you more of a forward view.Needless to say, this game is definitely a lot of fun. When it comes to a Yes/No scenario - a much easier type of review to do than an actual SCOCRE - I have to give this one a "GO".

Posted: August 12, 2014
												This is a game that your children would enjoy... provided they can learn the controls. I haven't gotten very far into it, but from what I've seen, you play a mad scientist inventor type who enjoys his life in a lakeside cabin. The game begins with an overly cartoony cutscene showing that the bad guys have drained the lake for their evil purposes. Being the only one who cares about the lake, your character rushes out to battle in a steam-powered buggy -- which is ironic due to the fact that all the water (the source of steam) has been stolen.Story aside, this game has a lot of irritations. (I wouldn't call them flaws -- the game is certainly playable, but it has minor annoyances that make the game unattractive.) The artwork is quite nice, but the humor expressed through the animation is slapstick and childish. Again, this would make a great game for children.A major irritation (at least with keyboard and mouse) is the akwardness of the controls. For one, hard turning is impossible without getting disoriented. Also, you can't shoot and drive in different directions. Your aim is locked forward, which means that you can either finish the level within the time limit or with max kills.Secondly, you're constantly being pushed forward. If you stop for a collectible, the enemies pass you, you can't catch up to them, and you're stuck with no pressure (fuel) and no powerups to attain more pressure.Third, every level is more or less the same. I understand that most games (especially level-based games like this) can't stray too far from the original concept without making the game incredibly difficult to play or incredibly difficult to program. However, it seems as though you just have to shove your way through (battering ram is the only useful upgrade) while holding "w" the whole time for every single level.Lastly, and, arguably, most irritating, is that you can't replay levels. There comes a point in the game when you just can't go any further without upgrades. At the same time, you don't have the money for the upgrades. The only way you can get money is by completing levels, but you can't replay them. Not to mention that if I just thought level 7 was cool and wanted to replay it, I wouldn't be able to. Sorry, you can't try for a better score. Sorry, you can't gain more coins to spend on upgrades. Sorry, you can't just play through a previous level for fun.All in all, this game can be fun if you don't get irritated by all the little nuances that make it difficult to enjoy. If you're anything like me, however, this game may provide half an hour's worth of entertainment every month or so.

												The game's plot is about a boy named Morgan who woke up, wanted to take a dive in a river only to find out all the water is stolen by Count Soap II to use for his hotel ( i think). So you set out to stop the count and get back your precious water. As you can see from the plot, the game is quite playful and funny.The game is basically, you shoot your enemies and earn pressure, pass through checkpoints ( passing through check points grants health and pressure), try to grab some gold along the way, and cross the finish line. It's simple as that but it sure is fun. A tip for those who will play this game, use your boost often as it r equires no pressure or anything and also just spam your gun.The presentation of the game is well done. The poster of the game in steam somehow tells us what the game is like and showing a funny looking characters.The graphics of the game is also great. You have a bird's eye view(I think its called top down, i'm not sure) as you control Morgan and his buggy. The colors are wonderfully chosen and gives life to the world. Also during gameplay, so much is happening, explosions, rockets firing, jumping cars. flying minions, etc and yet the game remains to run smoothly.The game's mechanic is nice but some need improvement I find it that the controls is too wobbly. You control the buggy using WASD or the Arrow keys and it always felt that it has too much sensitivity and you are unable to adjust this in the settings. Another thing is the upgrade menu, for the first 3 hours, I thought I can only upgrade my gun which is why I had a horrible time finishing some of the levels. I only found out later that I have to click the arrows with my mouse to change to other upgrades (I've been using the keyboard most of the time). Lastly, you are unable to replay previous levels which means you cannot try to earn more gold for upgrades. This means you have too choose which to upgrade wisely, but you can still sell the previous upgrade but for less.The sound used is that funky upbeat arcade music. This makes you feel like you are playing inside an arcade and it really compliments the game.Overall, the game is a bit hard sometimes because you may get overwhelmed by a dozen of enemies. I had some hair pulling and face palming moments but that just makes victory so much sweeter.Check out more game reviews by me and other people here: https://cassus.org/
